user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of build_connection_chunked_response_footer:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
build_connection_chunked_response_footer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  char *buf;           /**< the buffer to write footers to */
  size_t buf_size;     /**< the size of the @a buf */
  size_t used_size;    /**< the used size of the @a buf */
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  mhd_assert (connection->rp.props.chunked);
  /* TODO: allow combining of the final footer with the last chunk,
   * modify the next assert. */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_SENT == connection->state);
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->rp.response);

  buf_size = connection_maximize_write_buffer (c);
  /* '5' is the minimal size of chunked footer ("0\r\n\r\n") */
  if (buf_size < 5)
    return MHD_NO;
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->write_buffer);
  buf = c->write_buffer + c->write_buffer_append_offset;
  mhd_assert (NULL != buf);
  used_size = 0;
  buf[used_size++] = '0';
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  for (pos = c->rp.response->first_header; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (MHD_FOOTER_KIND == pos->kind)
    {
      size_t new_used_size; /* resulting size with this header */
      /* '4' is colon, space, linefeeds */
      new_used_size = used_size + pos->header_size + pos->value_size + 4;
      if (new_used_size > buf_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->header, pos->header_size);
      used_size += pos->header_size;
      buf[used_size++] = ':';
      buf[used_size++] = ' ';
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->value, pos->value_size);
      used_size += pos->value_size;
      buf[used_size++] = '\r';
      buf[used_size++] = '\n';
      mhd_assert (used_size == new_used_size);
    }
  }
  if (used_size + 2 > buf_size)
    return MHD_NO;
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  c->write_buffer_append_offset += used_size;
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= c->write_buffer_size);

  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function build_connection_chunked_response_footer:
const struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *first_header
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected the mhd_assert(...) statements because assertions are often implemented as macros that may be compiled out in certain builds; such statements can therefore become executed no-ops or be absent, which can lead to code that executes but whose removal does not affect observable program behaviour and thus should be reviewed for potential dead code. I also included the entire loop block that handles footer headers (the for/if/memcpy section) because that conditional path may never be exercised (no footer headers present) or could contain operations that are now redundant; it should be checked whether those writes/size calculations are ever required at runtime.

All other fragments in the function implement the core behavior of building the chunked footer and perform essential checks and buffer updates (calls to connection_maximize_write_buffer, the minimal-size check if (buf_size < 5), the explicit writes of '0\r\n' and final '\r\n', buffer bound checks, memcpy calls, and the update c->write_buffer_append_offset). Removing those would change program behaviour (e.g. corrupt output, buffer overruns, or incorrect returns), so they are not reported as suspicious for dead code.
